Article Title: Everton win first match after Sean Dyche's departure, beat Peterborough in FA Cup
Article Text:
AP Photo

Everton ended ties with manager Sean Dyche on Thursday, but it didn't affect their game on the field in the FA Cup third round, where they defeated League One side Peterborough 2-0.However, Everton, while seeking a manager to replace Dyche, find themselves in another relegation battle in the Premier League, having secured just one victory in their previous 11 fixtures, which came against struggling Wolves in December.They have just three victories in 19 league matches so far to be positioned 16th in the table.On Thursday morning, Dyche visited the Everton training facility to bid farewell after his termination, with his column still appearing in the Peterborough match programme.The team against Peterborough was managed by former Everton full-back Leighton Baines, currently the under-18s coach, alongside club captain Seamus Coleman, utilising Dyche's pre-selected starting eleven.Peterborough nearly secured a surprising first-half advantage when Cian Hayes' low shot was cleared from the goal-line by Jarrad Branthwaite.Beto managed to lift the spirits of Everton's quiet supporters in the 42nd minute when he received Harrison Armstrong's pass in the box, went past Peterborough goalkeeper Nicholas Bilokapic and placed the ball into the unguarded net.Everton faced a setback when their Chelsea loanee striker Armando Broja required oxygen and was carried off the pitch with his right ankle heavily bandaged.The anticipated family moment didn't materialise for Everton's Ashley Young, who was introduced late in the match, whilst his son Tyler, a Peterborough player, remained on the bench.In the final moments, Branthwaite was brought down by Jadel Katongo, leading to Iliman Ndiaye successfully converting the penalty, ensuring Everton's victory in their first match following Dyche's departure.
Article Summary: Everton defeated League One side Peterborough 2-0 in the FA Cup third round. Sean Dyche was sacked as manager of the Toffees on Thursday. The team was managed by former Everton full-back Leighton Baines. Everton are currently 16th in the Premier League.

Article Title: ISL: Odisha FC rally late to snatch 2-2 draw against Chennaiyin FC
Article Text:
Odisha FC vs Chennaiyin (Photo Credit: @OdishaFC on X)

CHENNAI: Chennaiyin FC head coach Owen Coyle has had to be content with a depleted squad for much of the ongoing Indian Super League season and it was no different on Thursday.In what has been a challenging campaign for Chennaiyin, Coyle has had to deal with absence of players at different junctures due to injuries, illness and suspensions. The Scottish manager was forced to field an all-Indian backline for the second successive match as overseas defenders Ryan Edwards and Elsinho were unavailable for selection.While CFC captain Edwards missed out because of a viral infection, Elsinho was not cleared to play, having returned to training after recovering from a nasty head injury. The forced team selection proved to be a blessing in disguise until their absence haunted Chennaiyin in their exciting 2-2 draw with Odisha FC at the Jawaharlal Nehru Stadium .Three of the four attack-minded foreign players picked in the XI were actively involved in Chennaiyin’s goals, before the hosts let go of a two-goal advantage at the end. The result was far from ideal for either team, with playoff challengers CFC (10th with 16 points) and OFC (7th with 21 points) staying in the same positions that they started the match at.After an uninspiring first half that was deprived of clear-cut opportunities, the combine of Wilmar Jordan Gil (48th and 53rd minute) and Connor Shields lit up the venue with quick-fire goals. Coyle’s half-time team talk appeared to have worked its magic as the hosts came out all guns blazing post the 15-minute interval.The opening goal arrived after Chennaiyin duly punished an Odisha error. Goalkeeper Amrinder Singh, trying to initiate an attack from the back and find Puitea, played a poor pass and an alert Shields pounced on it. The versatile Scotsman went on a run and put the ball on a platter for Jordan, who made no mistake from close range.The pair combined again a few minutes later. After Daniel Chima Chukwu won a duel with Mourtada Fall close to the halfway line, Shields burst forward on the left and made a simple pass to Jordan. The striker only had Amrinder to beat and did not pass the opportunity.When it seemed like Chennaiyin were on course for a much-needed win, Odisha made the contest interesting 10 minutes from time. Dorielton (80th minute) halved the deficit, seemingly from an off-side position that went unnoticed by the linesman, after substitute Diego Mauricio delivered a killer strike.Then, in the eighth minute of stoppage time, the tourists broke CFC hearts and rescued a point. Rahul KP’s shot from a bicycle-kick took a double deflection – the second being a wicked one – as it went in after hitting goalkeeper Mohammad Nawaz.
Article Summary: Chennaiyin FC draw 2-2 with Odisha FC at the Jawaharlal Nehru Stadium. Wilmar Jordan Gil (48th and 53rd minute) and Connor Shields lit up the venue. Dorielton (80th minute) halved the deficit, seemingly from an off-side position that went unnoticed by the linesman.

Article Title: Real Madrid enter Spanish Super Cup final with emphatic win
Article Text:
AP Photo

Jude Bellingham and Rodrygo did the scoring duties as Real Madrid secured am emphatic 3-0 win over Real Mallorca on Thursday to set up a mouth-watering 'Clasico' Spanish Super Cup final against archrivals Barcelona.With strong support from the crowd in Jeddah, Madrid opened scoring through Bellingham's precise finish after the first half, as Martin Valjent's own goal in stoppage time extended their lead, followed by Rodrygo's close-range finish to seal the scoreline.Real Madrid dominated the initial phase against the previous season's Copa del Rey finalists, with both Lucas Vazquez and Rodrygo nearly scoring in the first few minutes, and Kylian Mbappe seeking a penalty decision after contact with Dani Rodriguez.Under Jagoba Arrasate's guidance, Mallorca established themselves defensively and successfully limited the Spanish and European champions' attacking opportunities throughout the first half.Real Madrid faced a setback when Aurelien Tchouameni left the pitch early in the second half following a head collision with Cyle Larin, although he later confirmed he had not sustained any injury.Real Madrid found their breakthrough in the 63rd minute via Bellingham, following unsuccessful attempts by Rodrygo and Mbappe that were thwarted by both the woodwork and Mallorca's keeper Dominik Greif.The decisive moment came from a swift Madrid attack when Vinicius Junior's cross found Rodrygo, whose header struck the post, followed by Mbappe's shot being saved by the alert Greif.Bellingham demonstrated his clinical finishing ability by calmly guiding the loose ball past the defenders stationed on the goal-line, further extending his impressive scoring streak.Despite Vinicius and Mbappe having a subdued performance compared to their usual standards, their involvement in the first goal demonstrated the team's attacking prowess.Real Madrid's second strike was an own-goal gift from Valjent, who inadvertently directed the ball into his net whilst attempting to intercept a pass, leaving Mallorca with a mountain to climb.The match concluded with tensions flaring between both sides, particularly involving Mallorca defender Pablo Maffeo and Madrid's Raul Asencio, who engaged in a heated exchange.Rodrygo sealed the victory in the closing stages, ensuring Madrid's progression to face their rivals from last year's final.
Article Summary: Real Madrid beat Real Mallorca 3-0 in the Spanish Super Cup in Jeddah. Jude Bellingham and Rodrygo scored the goals for the Spanish champions. Martin Valjent scored an own goal in stoppage time to make it 2-0.

Article Title: Struggling Premier League club Everton sack manager Sean Dyche
Article Text:
Sean Dyche. (Pic Credit - X)

Everton Football Club on Thursday sacked their manager Sean Dyche on Thursday, ahead of their FA Cup third-round match against Peterborough.The team currently sits precariously close to the bottom three, with only a single point separating them from the relegation positions, having secured only three victories in their initial 19 Premier League fixtures this season.The club released an official statement announcing that Dyche "has been relieved of his duties as senior men's first-team manager with immediate effect" and confirmed they had begun searching for his replacement.Following reports that Everton's new proprietors, the US-based Friedkin Group, had initiated discussions with potential replacements after acquiring the Liverpool-based club, rumours regarding Dyche's position had grown.The Merseyside club has maintained its position in England's highest division since 1954, though recent seasons have seen them repeatedly battle against relegation.Dyche, aged 53, becomes the sixth Premier League manager to depart this season, following Julen Lopetegui's dismissal from West Ham on Wednesday, with Graham Potter subsequently taking charge.
Article Summary: Everton sack manager Sean Dyche with immediate effect. Dyche becomes sixth Premier League manager to be sacked this season. Everton currently sit in the bottom three of the Premier League table. The Merseyside club face Peterborough in the FA Cup third round on Saturday.

Article Title: Unwell Luka Modric to miss Real Madrid's Spanish Super Cup semi-final
Article Text:
Luka Modric. (Real Madrid Photo)

NEW DELHI: Luka Modric will not participate in the Spanish Super Cup semi-final match between Real Madrid and Mallorca on Thursday in Jeddah , Saudi Arabia, due to illness."Our player Luka Modric is out of the game against Mallorca today because of a viral illness," Real Madrid announced in their official statement.The 39-year-old Croatian midfielder recently achieved a milestone by becoming Real Madrid's oldest goalscorer with his strike against Valencia in La Liga last week.Barcelona have already secured their spot in Sunday's final in Jeddah after defeating Athletic Bilbao in Wednesday's semi-final encounter.
Article Summary: Luka Modric will miss Real Madrid's Spanish Super Cup semi-final against Mallorca. The 39-year-old Croatian midfielder is suffering from a viral illness. Barcelona have already secured their spot in Sunday's final in Jeddah.

Article Title: Wolves sign Ivory Coast defender Emmanuel Agbadou from Reims
Article Text:
Emmanuel Agbadou. (Premier League Photo)

Wolves have confirmed the acquisition of Ivory Coast defender Emmanuel Agbadou from Reims for £16.6 million ($20.3 million) on Thursday, marking the first signing under newly appointed manager Vitor Pereira .The 27-year-old defender has committed to a four-and-a-half-year contract at Molineux, with a provision for an additional year extension.Beginning his professional journey at Tunisia's Monastir, Agbadou later played for Eupen in the Belgian Pro League before joining Reims. He has been with the Ligue 1 club for the past two-and-a-half seasons, serving as team captain this season.Upon joining, Agbadou expressed enthusiasm about representing a "historic club"."I'm a player who likes to play football, I'm strong also, and I'm a leader in the defence. I think I can use this leadership for this team, and the coach told me about that also, it's for that I'm here, so I can help him with my leadership," he stated.Sporting director Matt Hobbs praised the new signing: "Emmanuel's a winner and he's driven. After the journey he has had, he's still unbelievably hungry. He's the type of player the Wolves fans should love, because you're going to get absolutely everything he's got."Pereira's appointment as manager occurred last month following Gary O'Neil's dismissal. The team currently sits above the Premier League relegation zone on goal difference after a 3-0 loss to Nottingham Forest on Monday.The team's next fixture is an FA Cup third round match against Bristol City on Saturday.
Article Summary: Emmanuel Agbadou joins Wolves from Reims for £16.6 million ($20.3 million) The defender has committed to a four-and-a-half-year contract at Molineux. The 27-year-old is the first signing under newly appointed manager Vitor Pereira.

Article Title: Sinner doping hearing at sports court fixed for April: CAS
Article Text:
Jannik Sinner. (Pic Credit - X)

The Court of Arbitration for Sport (CAS) has scheduled a hearing on April 16-17 for world number one Jannik Sinner regarding doping allegations, as announced by the Lausanne-based organisation on Friday.Following Sinner's positive tests for clostebol, a prohibited steroid, in March last year, the World Anti-Doping Agency has challenged the International Tennis Integrity Agency's (ITIA) decision to clear him.The hearing will be private, with CAS confirming that no parties requested a public session.The ITIA had previously accepted Sinner's explanation that the substance entered his system via his physiotherapist's use of a spray containing clostebol during treatment and subsequent therapy sessions.Prior to the Australian Open , the 23-year-old champion expressed uncertainty about the timing of the verdict, stating: "I know exactly as much as you guys know. We are in a stage where we don't know many, many things."Facing Chilean Nicolas Jarry in the first round at Melbourne Park, Sinner acknowledged the ongoing impact of the situation: "You think about this, of course. I would lie if I would tell you I forget. It's something what I have with me now already for quite a long time. But it is what it is. I'm here trying to prepare the Grand Slam. Let's see how it goes."Emphasising his cautious approach, Sinner explained: "I've always been very, very careful on every single medicine I take, even what I eat. When the bottle is open, I throw it away, I take a new one. In my mind I know exactly what happened, and that's how I block it (out). I haven't done anything wrong, that's why I'm still here. That's why I'm still playing."
Article Summary: Court of Arbitration for Sport has scheduled a hearing for world number one Jannik Sinner. Sinner tested positive for clostebol, a prohibited steroid, in March last year. World Anti-Doping Agency has challenged the International Tennis Integrity Agency's (ITIA) decision to clear him.

Article Title: Felix Auger-Aliassime beats Tommy Paul to enter Adelaide final
Article Text:
Felix Auger-Aliassime. (Pic Credit - X)

Felix Auger-Aliassime advanced to the Adelaide International final on January 13 after a gruelling victory over Tommy Paul , winning 7-6 (7/3), 3-6, 6-4 in nearly three hours.The Canadian, seeking his sixth title, will compete in his 16th career final against second seed Sebastian Korda , who defeated Miomir Kecmanovic of Serbia 6-4, 7-6 (7/4).Paul missed his chance to enter the top 10 rankings for the first time. The match was error-prone, with over 90 unforced errors. Paul showed resilience by claiming six of seven games in the second set."I'll try and recover now for the final," Auger-Aliassime said. "The match was about physical and mental effort. There were a lot of ups and downs."It was not the best level from either of us, but sometimes matches are like that, you have to find a way through."In the women's draw, top-seeded Jessica Pegula secured a 7-6 (7/4), 6-3 victory against Yulia Putintseva. She will face fellow American Madison Keys in Saturday's final.The two Americans, who have split their previous encounters, are making history as the first US women to reach this stage in Adelaide. Pegula returns to her first final since the US Open in September.Despite Putintseva's previous day's lengthy match, Pegula acknowledged the challenge. "I was on my toes, I knew she would try and break up the rhythm."I tried to play my game, I knew she would be tricky; I got a bit lucky in the tiebreaker."Keys, defending her 2022 title, progressed after Liudmila Samsonova retired at 5-7, 7-5, 3-0. Samsonova withdrew due to right knee issues."I'm excited to be in another final here," Keys said. "I was really happy to stay in the match. She played unbelievable at the start."It's not how you want to win (through retirement) but I'm glad I was able to stick around and tough it out."
Article Summary: Felix Auger-Aliassime beats Tommy Paul 7-6 (7/3), 3-6, 6-4 in nearly three hours. Canadian will play Sebastian Korda in his 16th career final. Top-seeded Jessica Pegula beats Yulia Putintseva to reach women's final. Pegula will face fellow American Madison Keys.

Article Title: Bhambri-Olivetti pair exits ASB Classic with semi-final defeat
Article Text:
Albano Olivetti and Yuki Bhambri. (Pic Credit - X)

NEW DELHI: Yuki Bhambri from India and his French partner Albano Olivetti lost their semi-final match at the ASB Classic in Auckland , despite a promising beginning.The unseeded Bhambri-Olivetti duo initially held control, but succumbed to the tournament's top seeds Nikola Mektic and Michael Venus , who secured a 3-6, 6-1, 5-10 victory in the ATP 250 event's semi-final contest.For their performance in the hard court competition, Bhambri and Olivetti each earned 90 points and shared $10150 in prize money.The collaboration proved beneficial for India's second-ranked player Bhambri, who had previously partnered with Venus, helping him prepare effectively for the upcoming Australian Open .
Article Summary: Yuki Bhambri and Albano Olivetti lose semi-final match at ASB Classic in Auckland. Top seeds Nikola Mektic and Michael Venus win 3-6, 6-1, 5-10 in ATP 250 event. India's second-ranked player had previously partnered with Venus.

Article Title: Defending champion Jannik Sinner all set for Australian Open amid doping clouds
Article Text:
Jannik Sinner. (Pic Credit - X)

The skies are blue and the sun is unapologetically brazen, not uncommon in the Antipodes this time of the year. Melbourne Park , the sprawling grounds of the Happy Slam, overlooks the Yarra, gliding gently alongside a shimmering carpet.The Australian Open , starting Sunday, is held far from the ructions of a world in a twirl, but even thousands of aeronautical miles isn’t quite far enough for tennis, struggling to move forward from issues of the past year. Ostensibly, a pair of gold standard 23-year-olds, World No. 1 Jannik Sinner and five-time major winner Iga Swiatek , returned positive tests that rocked the core of the game.Sinner, the Australian Open’s defending champion tested positive for clostebol last March. An independent panel, which was presented the case by the International Tennis Integrity Agency, ruled there was ‘no fault or negligence’ on the part of the Italian.The verdict that Sinner bore no fault didn’t sit well with the World Anti-Doping Agency , who in the era of XXL entourages, harps on independent thinking, especially with all that athletes put in their system. Not even a billionth of a gram.WADA has appealed to the Court of Arbitration for Sport and the Italian faces a potential ban of up to two years. The hearing could be slated for February after the conclusion of the first major of the year, but there could be appeals at a higher port, the Swiss Tribunal.Swiatek, the four-time Roland Garros champion, tested positive for trimetazidine in August. The sleep medication she was taking was contaminated.Tennis couldn’t have imagined a darker quandary in the New Year, given that the younger generation of champions had served notice of a new order last season.Sinner and Swiatek, who’ve been careful about everything they put in their body, came out with resilient masks on Media Day on Friday, saying, not much has changed for them.“I’ve done the same thing,” Sinner said. “Before I was very, very careful with every single medicine I took, even what I eat. When the bottle is open, I throw it away, I take a new one.”Swiatek, the four-time Roland Garros champion, who is playing down under with a new coach Belgian Wim Fissette, said, “The contaminated thing was a medication, and medications are treated as tested and clean. The weirdest thing is that the contamination level was ok by Polish pharmaceutical law, but it's not okay in our doping law.”Nick Kyrgios, who has unequivocally taken aim at Sinner, has stopped at nothing – personal or professional.“Having two number ones implicated in doping is abhorrent for our sport,” Kyrgios told reporters in Brisbane. “Right now the state of tennis integrity is widely acknowledged to be terrible – no one seems willing to address it, but it truly is unacceptable. We owe it to the sport to be vocal about it.”The volatile Aussie is backed by Djokovic, going for a historic 25th major title at Melbourne Park, and will open his campaign for a record-equalling 11th Australian Open crown against Indian-American Nishesh Basavareddy.The 37-year-old said, “I'm questioning the way the system works, why certain players are not treated the same as other players.”Interestingly, Sinner, who starts his campaign on Tuesday against Nicolas Jarry, who had tested positive for Lindanrol and Stanozolal and was suspended from the Tour for ten months from January 2020. He was subsequently cleared as the ITF ruled that Jarry ‘bore no significant fault or negligence for his violation’.Sinner, who wore his unruly crown and a blank expression like a model on a catwalk, didn’t give much away.“I haven't done anything wrong, that's why I'm still here,” the world No.1 said. “I don't want to respond to what Nick said or what other players say. The most important part is to have my people around me, they know exactly what happened.”Djokovic’s glittering trophy cabinet should serve as an example for Sinner. The Serb, not really a fan favourite, especially in a cast that included rockstar figures Roger Federer and Rafael Nadal, channelled his energies into winning, Grand Slam after Grand Slam, owning record after record, silencing raging crowds with his inner steel. In doing so he delivered a message that said, love means nothing in tennis, titles are everything.Sinner wouldn’t want to be known only as a two-time major winner, and Swiatek, a five-time champion, the shine and sparkle of silverware could wipe the smudge off their names. Melbourne Park is as good a place as any to get that going again.
Article Summary: World No. 1 Jannik Sinner and five-time major winner Iga Swiatek return positive tests. Sinner, the Australian Open’s defending champion tested positive for clostebol last March. WADA has appealed to the Court of Arbitration for Sport and the Italian faces a potential ban of up to two years.

Article Title: 'Imagine Messi as Ronaldo’s coach': Daniil Medvedev while discussing Novak Djokovic and Andy Murray
Article Text: Novak Djokovic and Andy Murray, long-time tennis rivals, have surprised the sports world with Djokovic hiring Murray as his coach for the Australian Open. The pair, who have faced off 36 times, are now openly sharing insights. While this partnership's future remains uncertain, Djokovic values Murray's high tennis IQ and recent playing experience.
Article Summary: Novak Djokovic and Andy Murray, long-time tennis rivals, have surprised the sports world with Murray as his coach for the Australian Open. The pair, who have faced off 36 times, are now openly sharing insights. While this partnership's future remains uncertain, Djakovic values Murray's high tennis IQ and recent playing experience.

Article Title: Naomi Osaka to compete in Australian Open following recovery from 'devastating' injury
Article Text:
Naomi Osaka (AP Photo)

Naomi Osaka confirmed on Friday her participation in the Australian Open 's first round, despite an abdominal injury sustained last week.Osaka reached her first final since 2022 in Auckland but retired injured after winning the first set against Clara Tauson .“In that moment it was devastating,” admitted Osaka, a two-time Australian Open champion and former world number one.Osaka expressed her disappointment, explaining how her physical condition hampered her performance.“It just sucked because I felt like my body wasn't keeping up with what my mind wanted it to do.”She also voiced concerns about her Australian Open prospects.“Obviously I was very concerned about my chances playing here,” Osaka told reporters at Melbourne Park, where the first Grand Slam of the year begins on Sunday.Osaka underwent a scan to assess the injury, revealing mixed results.“The MRI, it wasn't fantastic, but it wasn't bad at the same time.”Despite the scan results, she confirmed her participation in the upcoming match.“I'm pretty optimistic about playing my match. I mean, for sure I'm going to play my match.”She added that her practice sessions have been encouraging.“I've been practising pretty well for the two days that I've been here, so it seems to be going good.”Osaka took a 15-month break from tennis in 2023 for the birth of her first child and returned to the circuit 12 months ago.Currently ranked 50th, Osaka previously won the Australian Open in 2019 and 2021, two of her four Grand Slam titles.She is scheduled to face Caroline Garcia , ranked 58th, in the first round, a repeat of their 2023 encounter which Garcia won.Osaka acknowledged the challenges of returning to professional tennis after childbirth.“After giving birth, it was definitely really tough to even run,” the 27-year-old said.She empathized with the difficulty of regaining professional form after giving birth.“I do understand why it's very difficult to even get (back) to a professional level.”Osaka emphasized the absence of a standardized postpartum recovery plan in professional tennis.“There is no guidebook. But you kind of just go off what your body says.”
Article Summary: Naomi Osaka confirms her participation in the Australian Open. The 27-year-old suffered an abdominal injury in Auckland last week. Osaka is a two-time Australian Open champion and former world number one. She is scheduled to face Caroline Garcia in the first round.

Article Title: 'Control freak' Iga Swiatek shares her shock and the 'chaos' surrounding doping ban revelation
Article Text:
Iga Swiatek. (Pic Credit - X)

Iga Swiatek opened up about the challenging experience of her recent doping ban. She spoke about the emotional toll it took on her ahead of the Australian Open.Swiatek withdrew from the WTA 's Asian swing in September, initially citing "personal matters."It was later revealed that her absence was due to a one-month suspension for a positive doping test. The banned substance was a heart medication.Swiatek maintains she unknowingly ingested the substance through contaminated non-prescription medication.“Trust me, I was the one that was the most surprised.”Swiatek described the initial weeks following the news as a period of uncertainty and distress.“I had no idea what's going to happen. The first three weeks, I would say, were pretty chaotic. I had no idea if my suspension was going to be lifted soon or not.”She candidly shared the emotional impact of the situation.“It was probably the worst time in my life.”Swiatek expressed her frustration with the lack of control she felt.“And the fact that I had no control over this whole situation and I had no chance to avoid it made it even worse because I'm a control freak a little bit.”Following the ban, Swiatek returned to competitive play at the United Cup . She secured four consecutive singles victories before losing to Coco Gauff in the final.“I think it was great preparation before the first Slam.”Swiatek expressed confidence in her game leading into the Australian Open.“I think the quality of my game was also really nice. It also gave me some confidence.”The world number two is set to begin her Australian Open campaign against Katerina Siniakova. Siniakova is a Czech doubles specialist ranked 46th in singles.Several seeded players are in Swiatek’s half of the draw. These include fourth seed Jasmine Paolini , sixth seed Elena Rybakina , and eighth seed Emma Navarro .A potential matchup with world number one and defending champion Aryna Sabalenka could only occur in the final.Swiatek's history at the Australian Open has been less successful than at other Grand Slams. She has reached the second week of the tournament only once, in 2022. Her run that year ended in the semifinals with a loss to Danielle Collins.
Article Summary: Iga Swiatek has opened up about the challenging experience of her recent doping ban. She spoke about the emotional toll it took on her ahead of the Australian Open. The world number two is set to begin her Australian Open campaign against Katerina Siniakova.

Article Title: Alexander Zverev believes he’s mentally ready to win his first Grand Slam in Melbourne
Article Text:
Alexander Zverev (AP Photo)

Alexander Zverev , currently ranked world number two, expressed confidence in his ability to secure his first Grand Slam title . However, he acknowledged Jannik Sinner as the strong favorite to defend his Australian Open championship.Zverev's recent victories at the Rome and Paris Masters 1000 tournaments have boosted his confidence going into the first major tournament of the year.His impressive performance last season, where he won more matches than any other player except Sinner, propelled him to his highest career ranking.Despite his success, a Grand Slam title has eluded Zverev for nearly a decade. His closest attempts were runner-up finishes at the 2020 US Open and the 2021 French Open “Look, I think everybody knows what I'm chasing. Everybody knows what my goal and my dreams are, right? It's to win.”“Going into a Grand Slam as the world number two, you have to have the mindset of: I want to win the tournament.”“That's how my mindset is.”Zverev's Australian Open campaign begins on Sunday against French wildcard entrant Lucas Pouille. A challenging path lies ahead if he aims to win the title.A potential quarter-final clash with sixth-ranked Casper Ruud is on the cards, followed by a possible semi-final encounter with either ten-time champion Novak Djokovic or third seed Carlos Alcaraz .Awaiting in the final could be Sinner.Zverev identified his main rivals for the title. He mentioned familiar names such as Sinner, Alcaraz, Djokovic, and Medvedev, the latter having previously won the tournament.“I think the usual names. Jannik, Alcaraz, Novak for sure is part of that list. Daniil (Medvedev), because he's done it before.”However, Zverev emphasized Sinner as the clear favorite for the championship. He highlighted Sinner’s significant lead in the rankings.“But I think the biggest favourite is still Jannik, who is very far up that list. He's still number one by a big margin.”
Article Summary: Alexander Zverev is currently ranked world number two. The German is aiming to win his first Grand Slam title at the Australian Open. He acknowledged Jannik Sinner as the strong favorite to defend his title. ZvereV's Australian Open campaign begins on Sunday.

Article Title: Coco Gauff vows to maintain composure in Australian Open title bid
Article Text:
Coco Gauff (AP Photo)

Coco Gauff , currently in excellent form, attributed her recent success to staying composed under pressure. This composure makes her a significant challenger to Aryna Sabalenka at the Australian Open .Sabalenka, the world's top-ranked player, is considered the favorite to secure her third consecutive title in Melbourne.Gauff, ranked third globally and only 20 years old, concluded 2024 by winning the China Open and the WTA Tour Finals .This winning streak continued into the new season with victories at the United Cup, including a straight-sets triumph over world number two Iga Swiatek . This victory propelled the United States to the championship.Gauff's first-round opponent is 2020 Australian Open champion and fellow American Sofia Kenin , a potentially challenging match-up. Gauff believes the key to her success lies in "being relaxed, being chilled."“I know I've been playing well, but I can't play well all the time, I know there's going to be some tough moments in this tournament and hopefully I can get through them.”Gauff made a coaching change after her US Open title defense ended in disappointment. She parted ways with Brad Gilbert and hired Matt Daly .This change immediately yielded positive results, including a win at the 1000-level tournament in Beijing. Gauff credits her new coaching team with helping her "staying in the moment and enjoying it as much as possible."“The results have obviously been good because of that, but just trying to learn to do that when the results aren't so good.”Gauff's enhanced comfort level, stemming from adjustments to her game, poses a threat to other players in the women's draw.Her serve was a particular area of concern during the US Open.“I think I have a bit more tools to work with. Also I think just going for my shots more, being more okay with missing, taking chances.”Gauff recognizes the need to evolve her playing style.“Before, I feel like I won a lot of matches just being able to get a lot of balls back. I realised that's not the way to play if I want to have more success.”Coco Gauff acknowledges the fluctuating nature of performance in professional tennis. She anticipates facing difficult moments during the Australian Open but remains confident in her ability to navigate them.Gauff credits her new coaching arrangement with Matt Daly for her improved focus and enjoyment of the game. She emphasises the importance of maintaining this mindset even when results are less favorable.Gauff expresses increased confidence in her game due to recent modifications. She is embracing a more aggressive approach, taking more chances, and accepting the possibility of missing shots. She understands that this shift is essential for greater success.
Article Summary: Coco Gauff is currently ranked third in the world. The 20-year-old won the China Open and the WTA Tour Finals. Gauff's first-round opponent is 2020 Australian Open champion Sofia Kenin. She credits her new coaching team with helping her "staying in the moment"

Article Title: Jannik Sinner claims innocence as ATP head confirms doping investigation follows protocol
Article Text:
Jannik Sinner (AP Photo)

Top-ranked tennis player Jannik Sinner addressed doping allegations on Friday, asserting his innocence while ATP chairman Andrea Gaudenzi affirmed the integrity of the process.Sinner, currently world number one, tested positive twice for the steroid clostebol in March.The International Tennis Integrity Agency (ITIA) cleared Sinner, accepting his explanation that the substance entered his system through a contaminated spray used by his physiotherapist.However, the World Anti-Doping Agency (WADA) appealed the ITIA's decision to the Court of Arbitration for Sport, leaving Sinner awaiting a final verdict and a potential suspension.Sinner maintained his innocence, emphasizing his meticulous approach to medications and nutrition.“When the bottle is open, I throw it away, I take a new one,” he explained, highlighting his caution.He reiterated his confidence in his actions.“In my mind I know exactly what happened, and that’s how I block it (out).”He affirmed his innocence and determination to continue playing.“I haven’t done anything wrong, that’s why I’m still here. That’s why I’m still playing.”Despite his focus on the upcoming Australian Open, where he faces a challenging first-round match against Nicolas Jarry , Sinner admitted the situation weighs on his mind.“You think about this, of course,” he acknowledged.He admitted the ongoing nature of the situation.“I would lie if I would tell you I forget.”He described the persistent nature of the issue.“It’s something what I have with me now already for quite a long time. But it is what is. I’m here trying to prepare the Grand Slam. Let’s see how it goes.”Sinner stated he had no further information on the WADA appeal's timeline.“I know exactly as much as you guys know.”He emphasized the lack of clarity on the situation.“We are in a stage where we don’t know many, many things.” Novak Djokovic recently called for increased transparency in tennis doping cases, suggesting potential disparities in treatment based on player ranking.Gaudenzi refuted these claims in an interview with the Australian Associated Press, emphasizing the proper handling of Sinner's case.“I genuinely believe there has been a lot of misinformation out there, which is unfortunate,” Gaudenzi stated, dismissing inaccuracies in reporting.He affirmed the impartiality of the process.“I am 100 percent sure that there has not been any preferential treatment. The process has been run by the book and according to the rules, by the ITIA.”While Djokovic expressed belief in Sinner's contamination explanation, he also criticized the lack of transparency throughout the process.Gaudenzi, however, stated he was only informed about the case shortly before the ITIA's announcement, emphasizing the independent nature of the investigation.“I initially was a bit shocked. (But) it is completely independent and they obviously went to an independent panel.”Gaudenzi urged patience while the process unfolds, expressing confidence in the sport's resilience even if Sinner faces a ban.“If that is the case, I think he’ll survive and I think we’ll survive. Overall, tennis is a very strong product,” he concluded, highlighting the enduring strength of the sport.
Article Summary: Top-ranked tennis player Jannik Sinner addressed doping allegations on Friday. ATP chairman Andrea Gaudenzi affirmed the integrity of the process. Sinner, currently world number one, tested positive twice for the steroid clostebol in March.

Article Title: Coco Gauff refines her serve and forehand for the 2025 Australian Open
Article Text:
Coco Gauff (AP Photo)

Coco Gauff participated in a mixed doubles exhibition at Rod Laver Arena a few days before the Australian Open . It was a lighthearted event for fun and charity. During the match, Gauff playfully announced her target serve speeds, getting closer to 200 kph (125 mph).After winning a game with her partner Andrey Rublev, Hall of Famer Lleyton Hewitt complimented her serving.“Great serving.”“Thanks. I've been working on it.”Gauff has been diligently working on her serve and forehand. These improvements position her as a potential challenger to two-time defending champion Aryna Sabalenka at the Australian Open.“It would be great to come home with the Australian Open trophy. But I think I've just learned to not put so much pressure on events, and just put pressure on development and how I'm playing. That takes the pressure off.”Gauff aims to focus on her development rather than the pressure of the event. She reflects on her semifinal loss to Sabalenka last year.“I mean, yeah, making the semis last year and losing to Aryna, the eventual champion - I feel like I can get there and cross that line.”Her first opponent will be fellow American Sofia Kenin , the 2020 Australian Open champion. This marks Gauff's first major appearance since her fourth-round loss at the U.S. Open, where she had 19 double faults.Gauff has made adjustments to her forehand and serve grips with new coach Matt Daly , who joined Jean-Christophe "JC" Faurel on her team. Brad Gilbert departed in September.These changes aim to address weaknesses in her game. Daly complements Faurel's coaching, focusing on the technical aspects while Faurel concentrates on footwork and shot selection.“It's just been a great combo. JC has brought me a lot of footwork and shot selection in my game. And Matt has helped me with the technical side of things - my serve, specifically, and other things, as well.”Gauff expressed gratitude for her coaches' smooth transition and their combined efforts."It's just a good combination that we have. I'm very thankful for them to make the transition as easy as possible, especially considering it is two people."Five-time Slam champion Iga Swiatek recently lost to Gauff in the WTA Finals and the United Cup final. These straight-set victories reversed Swiatek's previous 11-1 head-to-head dominance.Gauff's social media post captures her current mindset.“new szn, better me.”The WTA Finals championship, which included a victory over Sabalenka, is a significant milestone for Gauff.“It means a lot to me.”She acknowledges the importance of competing against top players.“and playing the best of the best makes me feel confident in my game.”Gauff's ambition is clear. “I want to win as many big trophies as possible and just fill the cabinet up.”
Article Summary: Coco Gauff has been diligently working on her serve and forehand. Gauff hopes to challenge two-time defending champion Aryna Sabalenka at the Australian Open. This marks Gauff's first major appearance since her fourth-round loss at U.S. Open.

Article Title: Satwiksairaj Rankireddy-Chirag Shetty storm into Malaysia Open semis
Article Text:
Satwiksairaj Rankireddy and Chirag Shetty (Photo credit: X)

NEW DELHI: India's Satwiksairaj Rankireddy and Chirag Shetty progressed to the semis in the men's doubles event at the Malaysia Open in Kuala Lumpur on Friday.The seventh-seeded pair defeated Malaysian opponents Yew Sin Ong and Ee Yi Teo 26-24, 21-15 in a contest that lasted 49 minutes.In the semifinals, Satwik and Chirag will face South Korea's Won Ho Kim and Seung Jae Seo.Satwik and Chirag were runners-up in the previous edition of the Malaysia Open.The first game was a closely fought contest. Both pairs were evenly matched throughout. At the mid-game interval, the Indian pair held a slim 11-9 lead. They further extended their lead to 18-16.The Malaysian pair then rallied, scoring three consecutive points to tie the game at 19-19. They even briefly took a 20-19 lead.Despite the pressure, Satwik and Chirag remained composed. They saved four consecutive game points. The Indian pair ultimately won the first game 26-24.In the second game, the Malaysian duo started strongly. They held the lead for a significant portion of the game, leading 11-8 at the interval.Satwik and Chirag mounted a remarkable comeback after the interval. They dominated the latter half of the second game.The Indian pair won 13 of the next 17 points, securing their victory and a place in the semifinals.
Article Summary: India's Satwiksairaj Rankireddy and Chirag Shetty progress to semifinals of Malaysia Open. The seventh-seeded pair defeated Malaysian opponents Yew Sin Ong and Ee Yi Teo 26-24, 21-15 in a contest that lasted 49 minutes. They will face South Korea's Won Ho Kim and Seung Jae Seo in the semifinals.
